body.value:
A lover of everything humanities, Ana Monteiro is a strong believer in pursuing something that one is passionate about.

Ana, 17, immigrated to the US from Portugal with her parents when she was a toddler, now lives in Newark, New Jersey and is a rising senior at Science Park High School. Growing up, Ana earned her motivation to work hard and help others after seeing her father struggle to make enough money for her family.

Even though she may not have the encouragement and support from her parents, Ana insists on doing what she loves in her future. Working for money instead of working for your interests is something that Ana despises, and hopes to never have to deal with. In the future, she plans on pursuing a career in writing, where she could be free to express her thoughts and be informed, all for one goal; to impact and make a positive difference in people’s lives.

Being treated as an adult from a young age had aided Ana in working hard to be involved in activities in school. Having started her own club, the “Socratic Circle Club,” where members can talk freely about topics without having the pressure of fighting to be right, Ana has determined that competitiveness is a negative factor in one’s life.

body.value:
Aaliyah Khan is conversant in the art of caring.

“Seeing the impact in front of you- that’s why I do it,” said Aaliyah as she reflected on her involvement in the humanities.  

Aaliyah is rising sophomore at Warren Hills Regional High School in Asbury, NJ (not the beach) and she is an involved student with high hopes of making an impact through broadcast journalism.

Conscientious and compassionate, Aaliyah is unafraid of speaking up against systematic marginalization and violence towards minority groups. As one of the only Muslim immigrant descendants and women of color at her school, Aaliyah has truly embodied the expression "voice of the voiceless."Joining school clubs like SAVE (Students Against Vandalism of the Earth) and the Human Rights club have allowed Aaliyah to discover her passion for humanitarian issues.

"I basically want to be a modern day MLK," said Aaliyah as she spoke about her dreams of using journalism as a tool to combat and expose the world's inequalities, especially against Muslim Americans.  

Her passion for helping others coupled with her interest in broadcast journalism drove Aaliyah to apply for the Hugh Boyd Journalism Workshop at Rutgers where she hopes to gain a better understanding of what journalism entails.

With a strong desire to travel the world and leave her mark, Aaliyah is making strides to affect the lives of those around her and beyond. She wants to travel to other countries and destruct the misconceptions surrounding the Islamic faith.

When asked where she sees herself in the future, Aaliyah didn’t hesitate.

“If all goes well I want to be able to be a journalist making a difference in the world.”

body.value:
Cassandra Vega stands out from her peers at the Hugh N. Boyd Diversity Workshop at Rutgers University because of her beautiful personality. During the workshop she displayed humor with friends and fun times, keeping positive vibes and smilies on her peers’ faces.

She's a 16 -year-old junior at South Brunswick High School who is always ready to learn new things.

When Vega was young she had big dreams of changing the world.

“I wanted to be the first woman president, lawyer and even a chemist,” she said.

But as she got older her aspirations changed. Now she sees herself going into the field of sports journalism.

“ I knew I loved to write and be in front of the camera, I want to do as much as I can,” she said.

She has been writing for her school newspaper since her freshman year. But she spends most of her time playing sports. She’s a member of the varsity track, cross country and basketball teams.

“I'm very competitive, like you know those people in gym who act like they are playing at NBA finals? Yeah, that’s me,” Vega said.

Vega and her teammates have many accomplishments to be proud of: Her 4x800 relay team broke the Middlesex County record of 9.28 minutes and went to nationals in Greensboro, N.C..

In addition to athletics, Vega also has a diverse taste in music. In her free time she listens to everything from indie music to rap and rock and roll.

“My top three have to be Childish Gambino, Erykah Badu and Panic at the Disco,” Vega said.

Vega has something different to bring to the world.

Said Vega, “I came to this program to become a better journalist and to improve my writing skills and to make connections that last a lifetime.”

body.value:
Always willing to help, Emili Kovell never hesitates to offer her services in return for nothing. Even if she’s working on something herself, all you need to do is ask and she’s there.

Born July 31, 2001 in St Peter’s Hospital in New Brunswick N.J., Emili was almost a Samantha. Her mother wanted her name to be Samantha but her father wanted her name to be Emili.

A 16-year-old senior at East Brunswick High School, Emili has spent her entire life with her nose in books.

”I love books, I just love holding books and flipping through books and reading them,” she said.

She admits to being the type of student to read her books during class under the table, and has even confessed to cutting her hair short and buying round glasses to mirror famed character Harry Potter. A fictional character of which she shares the same birthday and coincidentally an obsession that has led her to write “pages and pages” of fanfiction based on Harry Potter.

“I would have piles of lined paper just filled with Harry Potter fanfiction,” she said.

Emili wrote fanfiction before she knew what fanfiction was under the pen name “Lindsey Pruch”, a name of which she has no idea of the origin. Her fanfiction have revolved always completely around Harry Potter.

“The feeling of Harry Potter that I got when I read I just kinda wanted to experience that for longer,” she said.

Any music that sounds good is fair game for Emili. Some of her favorite bands are The Beatles, David Bowie and Pink Floyd. Although she may not want to admit it, she had an “emo phase” where she cut her hair to a pixie cut and listened to My Chemical Romance.

Her obsession with writing unknowingly armed Emili with the skills she would need in order to win third place in the SPJ/JEA High School Essay Contest. Her essay, which is titled “The State of the Truth”, revolves around the difficulty of countries unifying to solve problems when each country has different perceptions of the truth.

And earlier this year, Emili won a $300 scholarship for her efforts.

Despite her participation in the workshop, Emili does not see herself working as a journalist. She said she doesn’t feel as though she is outgoing enough. What she does want to do is help other aspiring writers get their books published as well as her own.

body.value:
Mecca Watterman is a classic case of why one shouldn’t judge a book by its cover.
 
First impressions of Mecca can leave one shocked to realize that under her dynamic, sassy personality, is a hard-working, and brilliant woman who, “doesn’t let her name define her.”
 
Mecca, a senior at Winslow Township High School in Atco, NJ, writes for her school paper, but her academic excellence isn’t all she is about.
 
She also gives back to the community, as her job is to take care of senior residents battling through mental disorders such as dementia and Alzheimer's.

“It’s hilarious working with them,” Mecca said. “They may not be in the right mindset but they know what they’re talking about.”

Mecca wants to do daring stunts such as bungee jumping, skydiving, and cliff diving. She has very few fears or phobias. In fact,  the only things she squirms at are centipedes and bugs that fly.
 
“I freaking hate centipedes,” Mecca said. “After watching the ‘Human Centipede’ I couldn’t sleep for three days.”
 
With little to no fear, and success in both academic and athletic fields, Mecca is a Jack-Of-All-Trades. If there are obstacles left in her path, Mecca has her eye on her goals- to work at NBC or the New York Times.

body.value:
When Tiffannie Coy was 12, she spent her time in the Wizarding World. In her mind.
 
Back then,she was busy reading the entire Harry Potter Series that year.
 
Today the  Science Park High School senior is even more infatuated with reading.
 
In addition to writing on her blog, she loves to read.
 
“Reading takes me into a different world,” she says.
 
One of her favorite things to do is go on vacations every year. Her favorite places to go are tropical, like Hawaii. “I’ve been to Hawaii 5 times,” she said. “My parents went once and bought a timeshare, so now we go all the time,” she added.
 
In her senior year, the 17-year-old will be on her high school soccer team. She has her own blog on Tumblr and is a freelance journalist. She wants her own podcast, but she says “Microphones are way too expensive for me right now.”
 
As college is approaching for her, she said to me “I plan on applying to 15 colleges, but I hope to go to either New York University or Brown University.” In college, she wants to pursue her writing as a career, but is not sure if she wants to major in Journalism or English.
 
Aside from Journalism as a whole, she wants to focus on mainstream and or passion writing because she thinks that “Writing about politics at a younger age is risky and it is easier to write things about politics when you are more experienced.”
 
“I plan on writing about celebrities or entertainment, I guess,” she told me.

body.value:
From fashion blogs to color guard, Crystal Durham of Jackson Memorial High School does it all. Born on August 8, 2001, Durham has always had an eye for style and followed her own rhythm.

“I fell in love with fashion from a young age,” said Durham.

She started blogging in 2016 on her website, www.iamcrystaallxo.wordpress.com, to express her creativity and empower black women through different forms of art.

Not only is she extremely well versed in fashion, she revamps clothes she finds in thrift shops and wears it herself.

Durham noted, “I’d rather go to the thrift store and make something unforgettable than wear something with no purpose.”

If that’s not enough, she teaches hip hop at West Side Dance in Jackson, New Jersey, the dance studio she went to as a child. She also participates in the color guard at her school, which is extremely visual - throwing rifles and sabers in the air. In addition to this, Crystal also models for local bridal companies on the side, which makes sense considering her confidence and beauty.

<>“I didn’t think I’d be doing so much, but now that I am, I want to surround myself with positive experiences and positive people,” Durham said.

She is not afraid to be herself, using inspirations like R&B singer Jill Scott and rapper Cardi B’s stylist Kollin Carter to help her find her voice. Though she doesn’t know the exact college she plans to attend, she wants to stay close to home and aspires to become a fashion journalist and host the Met Gala one day.

Said Durham, with a smile, “Throughout my journey, I want to inspire my fellow women in as many ways as possible.”

body.value:
Going to Point Pleasant Borough High School has always been a struggle for 16-year-old Natalie Andreyev because her school lacks diversity. Being Asian and White, she is one of the few students who are Asian in her school.

Doing a quick niche.com search on her high school she found out that a majority of her school is White and also very financially privileged; making it difficult for someone who is different to fit into a school of more than 900 students.

In light of this, she enjoys spending most of her time participating in her school’s stage choir. Natalie also prides herself on her acting skills and loves to tell people she got casted in two of the major plays her school has done; Beauty and The Beast and Grease.

In her square mile town, she gets to freely bike around to the nearby beach or the park.

She also enjoys spending free time with her brother and going to his hockey games. She’s very happy to be participating in the Boyd Journalism Workshop this summer to discover what area of journalism she likes the best. Sports Journalism has always been a huge part of Natalie’s life and in her future, she plans on working for the New Jersey Devils or for the NHL reporting on different sports across the country.

attributes.title: Video Basics with Professor Esther Dillard

body.value:
I’m trying to interview Esther Dillard, a professor of Communications at Bloomfield College. I’m an interviewer, but minutes ago I was a student. She purses her lips at my outstretched recorder.

“Bring that microphone closer,” she interrupts. “If you want to get good sound, you want to bring it close to the person, even if it seems like it’s a little obtrusive.”

I do as she says. She knows what’s she doing.

Professor Dillard has been a teacher for five years. Before that, she was a reporter for 12. She fell in love with print journalism as a writer for the newspaper at the University of Buffalo, but as an intern at The Buffalo News, she realized the unique impact that video could have.

“People would be like, ‘I saw that story, that was really fantastic,’ and they didn’t say that about mine because they didn’t read it,” she remembers.

The goals of a reporter and a teacher are similar, she says: “To inform, to educate, and to inspire.”

Throughout the week, she did just that for the 13 students of the Hugh N. Boyd Journalism Diversity Workshop on the same topics she covers in her own classes at Bloomfield College - video editing, interviewing, and writing for television. Once the basics were down - audio, different kinds of video cuts, the rule of thirds - students broke into groups and recorded interviews of each other with the skills they had learned.

The technical aspect of video journalism is not one that Dillard ever shied away from, though she was often writing scripts or speaking in front of the camera. It’s a part of journalism that Dillard believes is becoming more and more important for young journalists to embrace as photographer-journalist teams become obsolete.

One of the biggest misconceptions Dillard finds in her students is the belief that the job of a journalist is glamorous.

“As small as you are,” Dillard says, indicating my 5’2” frame, “you might have a camera, microphone, tripod, lighting equipment, and you have your car, and you are told to do the story.”

Some Boyd students began the workshop without any experience in the increasingly vital field of video journalism, but with Professor Dillard’s help, the learning curve was sharp. Cassie Vega was one of those fast learners.

Going into the program, she says, she “knew absolutely nothing” about iMovie. But by the second visit by Dillard, after no more than a quick introduction, Vega “was already half-way done with my project.”

Though classes were sometimes plagued by technical difficulties, the lessons that Dillard imparted will stay with each student journalist throughout his or her career, no matter which field he or she enters. The technical side of journalism isn’t always pretty, but with Dillard’s help, the finished product will be.

“It’s not about being pretty or wearing three-inch heels,” she says. “It’s about actually going out and doing the work.”

attributes.title: Student Activist Dares to Make a Difference

body.value:
Racial barriers are very damaging to one’s self-esteem and can become really discouraging. Few can accept and allow these boundaries to slow them down, while many choose to fight them. Toibat Ayankunbi chose to do the latter.

The story of Ayankunbi begins at Columbia High School in Maplewood, New Jersey, where she and other minorities had noticed racial separations between students. The school’s reputation is infamous because of the many lawsuits and accusations claiming that minorities were denied fair access to advanced classes.

“I was definitely sad about the lack of representation of students of color in honors classes, but once I realized that I could help in fixing the problem, I was galvanized to act,“ said Ayankunbi, referring to the absence of minorities in the classes.

In her high school, Ayankunbi recalls being one of few minorities in the honors classes she took. This ethnic divide motivated her to become a better person and help others who were not as fortunate to excel in these classes.

The Minority Achievement Community (MAC) is a program for students of different ethnicities to study and work hard, preparing them for honors classes. Ayankunbi is the president and squad leader in this program. Giving back to fellow students was her way of combating the racial differences in her high school.

“I liked the idea of having a support network of students and faculty that wanted to see me and my peers succeed,” mentioned Ayankunbi, highlighting her fondness of helping out her students.

In the MAC, Ayankunbi helped students out by starting study sessions, discussing their grades and how they could improve, and referring them to other sources of assistance when needed.

Ayankunbi’s work has gotten impressive results. When the group first started, only 20 students had been placed in advanced courses, but with Ayankunbi’s assistance, that number skyrocketed to 100, with 90 percent in honors classes.

“Truly, the accomplishment is all theirs. The students work insanely hard, putting in countless hours every day after school,“ Says Ayankunbi, believing the progress of the students were the result of the extraordinary dedication of the students.

Ayankunbi has accomplished extraordinary feats, such as becoming one of the few minorities in her honors classes, teaching students in the Minority Achievement Community, placed students in honors classes, and winning the Princeton Prize in race relations.

Despite her amazing accomplishments, the most perplexing trait about Ayankunbi is her age. Ayankunbi is only 17; this fall she’ll be a freshman in Rutgers’ Honors College. Despite her young age, Ayankunbi is a well respected community leader.

In regards to other students who had grown up in similar conditions, Ayankunbi has this advice: “Try to find a community of supporters, empowers, and motivators. In your darkest times, they will be the ones to pick you up.”

body.value:
On the surface, the Warriors winning championship after championship affects how the rest of the NBA builds their teams. This growing dynasty affects the business world, as well. Consumer goods are affected when Kevin Durant signs with Warriors as that causes Nike to block Under Armour from receiving all the spotlight after another championship victory.

This just hardly scratches the surface of what students of the Hugh Boyd Journalism Diversity Workshop at Rutgers heard from panelists Jordyn Holman, a diversity management reporter, and David Levitt, who covers commercial real estate mostly in New York, at the Bloomberg Headquarters in Manhattan.

Beforehand, the group of select students toured the headquarters and were quite amazed with what they saw. With the panel, they got a further explanation to the sights they saw in the building and took in lots of useful information during the session.  

The panelists set out to inspire the students. Holman gave good inspiration on what it means to be a journalist.

“Being a journalist is such a unique position to hold in society,” Holman said. “You’re always meeting new people and learning new things in the field.”

They also gave helpful tips for the students regarding their future in journalism.

“People will actually pay for business news in a way that they won’t when writing about something such as the city council,” Levitt said.

Furthermore, the panel members shared experiences with the students. Levitt, in particular, talked about writing about the sale of the World Trade Center just months before 9/11. He spoke about how American businessman Larry Silverstein took care of the property, a ninety-nine year lease that took many years to reconstruct after the sudden and horrific events that unfolded.

Holman and Levitt also explained that there are different interviews for different subjects that are being covered and that she is still learning how to interview everyday.  

Holman said, “You’re constantly learning how to do an interview. There’s a different interview style for every interview you do. A lot of the time I want to know as much about the person I’m talking to as possible.”

To end, Holman added that, outside of work a journalist needs a hobby of sorts to help them unwind from the newsforce.

“Have something else that you are interested in and putting your energy towards,” she said. “It’ll make you a better writer and keep you more energized when you are writing.”

attributes.title: Asbury Park Press Pushes Forward in Challenging Times

body.value:
In the Asbury Park Press newsroom in Neptune, NJ, brightly colored walls and Bon Jovi pictures framed the rows of computers where reporters sat with their heads down - eyes strained towards their screens. One desk appeared to stoop with the weight of animal and action figurines.

But what also stood out were the many empty desks; these days there are only 80 journalists on staff at the Press. There had been more journalists, but many had been laid off, editors said. It’s the biggest evidence of the changes in journalism. The industry is now focused on online numbers and digital access in comparison to the number of newspapers sold.

When the Boyd Journalism Workshop students entered the second floor of the building, they encountered an energy that didn’t seem to belong to a newsroom radically changed by technology.

Boyd students met with Alesha Williams Boyd (no relation), the Regional Director of Engagement, and were immediately struck with the realization that social media has taken over journalism. One of the students was given APP’s Snapchat account to control for the day and Boyd acknowledged that social media is a method for them to closely interact and reach out to a greater audience.

The importance of social media was also reflected by a large whiteboard that stretched across an entire wall. Different colored numbers were scrawled on the board. One color symbolized the APP’s goal for clicks on their website; other colors denoted the actual number of clicks recorded. Green indicated that the goal was met whereas red indicated that the clicks had fallen short of the goal.

Boyd and other staff members quickly affirmed that advancements in technology meant that a lot of journalism was based on numbers such as those written on their whiteboard; after analyzing them, they would be better able to improve their methods of reaching out to their audience.

It was another sign that the gradual decline of print has followed the rise of the digital age.

“More data now means we can tell exactly how many people interact with what we present,” said Paul D’Ambrosio, APP’s director of news and investigations. He is in charge of obtaining data, while Boyd and her team work on how to best present news to their audience.

Because of the swift changes in technology, journalists must learn how to adapt quickly to new ways of accessing an audience. They recognized they had to constantly learn because there is so much that changes in journalism everyday.

After discussing the numbers on the whiteboard, the students were immediately ushered into a conference room. There, summer interns and seasoned journalists gave counseling to the students.

Their biggest piece of advice?

“Go get internships,” said staff writer Stacy Barchenger.

On the other hand, to directly experience the life of APP journalists, Boyd students practiced being on camera and watched the process of creating and publishing an article. Many of the Boyd Journalism Workshop students want to pursue a career in broadcast journalism, so it was definitely enlightening for them to watch each other stare at the camera lens under the heat of the white lights.

Others said they enjoyed watching regional print planner Ilana Keller demonstrate how to produce an article that could appear on the APP website.

“It was really great. This visit only reaffirmed my vision to go into broadcast journalism,” said Boyd Workshop student Braedyn Speight.

The growing emphasis of APP’s website only affirms how its journalists are already embracing the newest stage of journalism. It almost seems as if numbers are just as important as words; however, APP will continue its mission of making an impact in New Jersey by sharing the news - no matter the form or method - quickly, ethically, and respectfully.

Only this time, it will be with the help of the new digital age.

body.value:
Imagine being stereotyped by your peers without them giving you a chance to introduce yourself and tell who you actually are. Redefy’s goal is to help teens share their stories.

Founded by Ziad Ahmad in 2013, when he was 13 years old, Redefy has been growing rapidly ever since. Redefy’s goal is to defy stereotypes, and to share stories of minorities that don't get told often.

Julia Chang and Justin Sherman of Redefy told their stories when they visited the Boyd Journalism Workshop.They explained why they joined Redefy, and it was extremely inspiring to the Boyd Journalists to know that other teenagers are going through the same issues.

According to the website, they aim to “...promote acceptance, defy stereotypes, and defeat hate” by sharing stories, providing resources, and generating discussion about topics that some people avoid talking about.

Julia Chang is the Director of Journalism and, like all her colleagues she is in high school. Julia attends Princeton Day School, and is an upcoming Junior. She and Justin,who also attends Princeton Day School as a rising junior, both said that it is definitely hard to balance high school and being on the leadership team, but they said that it is all worth it because they are making a difference in the world.

Justin Sherman,who is the Director of Operations at Redefy, said "People who are not exposed to different ethnicity or different people... they might be a little bit more prone to cling onto a stereotype because it's all that they've heard from a particular group, so we really want to bring as many people together so that stereotypes aren't the only thing influencing their judgement".

Both Julia and Justin said that "We truly believe that Redefy and its followers can unite to reach our goal of creating a judgment-free community. By sharing the stories of those who have encountered stereotypes, we create an online community where people can read about others’ struggles and relate to them."

"As young people, we are driven by the belief that it is our responsibility to ensure that tomorrow is better because we will live to see tomorrow. Teenagers have a natural instinct to rebel; if we channel our instinct towards a cause that will better our world, the outcome will be both beautiful and powerful,” also stated on Redefy's website.

Although society may think that high school students and teenagers are "too young" to have a say, Julia said “The goal of Redefy is to also show that teenagers are capable and we need to be discussing issues like this.”

Both Julia and Justin feel that if they can reach teenagers, then they can get their stories even further because it is now up to students to bring up important news.

A goal of Redefy is to create chapters all around the world. Julia and Justin ask that teenagers join together and join Redefy, even if they don't want to be a staff writer, they can still share their stories.

Most of the students in the room were excited to have Redefy in as a presentation because they can all relate to the whole team. Most students said while watching their presentation that they were excited to hear about this opportunity to write about their stories and share their stories about being a minority in this day and age.

Julia said to end the night,“Teens are the future of America, and it starts by sharing their stories.”

attributes.title: In The Red: College Debt a Major Concern for Many

body.value:
Students at Rutgers University take pride in being Scarlet Knights, but is this crimson crusade really worth it? Most students say financial aid played a big role in their college decision but many are now in debt. Students at Rutgers toe the line, knowing that every school year is a new battle between the bank and the classroom.

After graduating college, many students go out into the world, expecting to get a job and take care of themselves. But they often have overwhelming financial baggage. Students like Rutgers junior Ariana Grossi want that to change.

“No more paying debt till you’re 35 to 40 years old,” she said.

Rutgers senior Julie Koo said Rutgers was perfect because it was close to home and she received generous financial aid. But now, college debt is a nerve-wracking subject, especially as she plans to go to graduate school.

Koo said, “I feel rushed, since I see my friends are rushing to pay off their loans.”

Because Koo received scholarships her freshman year, she is now attending graduate school with an optimistic mindset, keeping her studies first and exercising to relieve stress.

Destiny Morales, a junior, loves attending Rutgers. For her, financial aid did not factor significantly into her decision.

“I always said that I didn’t want money to play a big role in what school I go to because it's not fair,” she said. “I want to go wherever I want to go because I worked hard.”

As an out-of-state undergraduate student, Morales has to pay at least $50,000 a year (compared to $35,000 for New Jersey residents). During her interview, she giggled stressfully, as she explained how she still owes $30,000. Morales mentioned receiving a scholarship for $3,500, then fell silent. That scholarship is not enough.

For Morales, college debt is always in the back of her mind. She said it sometimes gets in the way of her enjoying her life since she is constantly forced to set money aside to pay off her loans.

Every semester she worries,  “Are they really going to give me the money I need to go on to the next year? Like am I really going to keep going here but can I really afford it?”

These students are pressed with the task of investing in a bright future as well as handling their finances. They advise high school students to be realistic with picking schools.

“Don't just try to go far away,” said Nicollette Takacs, who graduated from Rutgers this year.

Koo thinks that community college is a good option for students who do not know what they want to do. She explained that if you are still undecided there are options to avoid wasting time and money.

Morales stressed the importance of applying for scholarships throughout one’s college years.

Said Morales, “Don't just stop after your senior year, because there are so many. Kids are distracted during the school year so it gives you a better chance to get one.”

Every semester she worries,  “Are they really going to give me the money I need to go on to the next year? Like am I really going to keep going here but can I really afford it?”

These students are pressed with the task of investing in a bright future as well as handling their finances. They advise high school students to be realistic with picking schools.

“Don't just try to go far away,” said Nicollette Takacs, who graduated from Rutgers this year.

Koo thinks that community college is a good option for students who do not know what they want to do. She explained that if you are still undecided there are options to avoid wasting time and money.

Morales stressed the importance of applying for scholarships throughout one’s college years.

Said Morales, “Don't just stop after your senior year, because there are so many. Kids are distracted during the school year so it gives you a better chance to get one.”
body.summary: Students at Rutgers University take pride in being Scarlet Knights, but is this crimson crusade really worth it?

attributes.field_article_author: Crystal Durham, Mateo Thomas and Emili Kovell

body.value:
As Google defines it, insecurity is “uncertainty or anxiety about oneself; lack of confidence.” What everyone knows to be true but fails to remind themselves, is that everyone has insecurities.

Many people will not admit their flaws or self doubts to anyone, but it became obvious throughout the interviews that some insecurities are more than skin deep.

John Regan swaggered down the street, playing some classic James Brown from his backpack. Despite this confident demeanor, he quickly opened up about his acne insecurity growing up, which often kept him from socializing with his friends. He soon learned that people are often harder on themselves than others are. His advice to his younger self and other young people was simple yet effective.

“Don’t overthink it. Don’t give it a second thought,” Regan said.

The flaws one might see in themselves are more often than not, invisible to their peers. One example of this is the internal vulnerability shared by Renee Wilson.

Wilson, a hyper organized young woman, was leaning peacefully against the wall outside of the Rutgers Barnes & Noble. She was quick to explain her decision-making issues and her debate between the stability of her current career and her passion on the side, though she has not made her final choice as of yet.

“I don’t want to leave something stable that’s making a lot of money. I’m kind of just juggling the two until the second thing I want to do becomes more lucrative,” added Wilson.

Jin Su Kin had a different kind of insecurity to share. As he nervously fumbled through the pages of the book gripped in his hand, Kin began to explain his unease in finding a job and how he feared people would look down on him for not having financial security. He explained the way he persevered as he constantly submitted job applications, never accepting no for an answer in his quest for mental peace in an ever-changing economy.

Amanda Navarro came up behind Su Kin while he finished talking about his motivation to make a life for himself in America. She soon began to explain her perseverance through an undisclosed insecurity.

When asked what she did to overcome her insecurity, her response was intriguing.

“I don’t know if I knew that I was insecure while it was happening,” Navarro said. “Through challenges and failure you learn to improve yourself and gradually accept yourself for everything you are.”

body.value:
Gender plays an enormous role in the toys parents buy for their children and it’s been like that for a while. Ever since toys were created they’ve been divided by colors and types: girls get the Barbies, boys get the action figures. But should it be like that?

It is undeniable that toys, a billion-dollar industry, have a pervasive effect on both parents and children. However, the debate lies in whether they should continue to be separated by gender.

Opinions are mixed about the need for gender specific toys today. In a brief survey around New Brunswick, people with children, more often than not, said they thought gender specific toys were helpful while people without children indicated the issue wasn’t a big deal.

Avin Roopa, whose child is attending summer college classes at Rutgers University, said, “I don’t see a problem with having gender specific toys.”

Balagi Natsan, whose child is also attending college classes, echoed Roopa’s thoughts.

“Yes, it helps actually, as parents like me, you know, sometimes especially when you're going for a big car, you know, or some toys in a hurry… it helps actually,” he said.

Younger people, especially those without children, disagreed.

“I think there doesn't necessarily need to be a division because kids can play with what they like regardless of gender,” said 31-year-old Trisha Aaningburg.

Rutgers student Ezra Oliff-Lieberman agreed, adding, “I think it perpetuates a gender binary that doesn’t exist and puts people into boxes and dictates what they should be and what they should like. And that creates a lot of problems with people.”

Experts agree with Oliff-Lieberman that toys do have a large effect on children’s futures.

Jeffrey Trawick-Smith, a professor of Early Childhood Education at Eastern Connecticut State University, said toys help shape the impressionable minds of children and can impact the social, intellectual, and creative areas of development depending on the type of toy they are. In an article from the National Association for the Education of Young Children’s website (www.naeyc.org), Trawick-Smith said toys marketed for boys usually offer a different set of skills, and subsequently different areas of development, than toys marketed for girls.

Some students do think that categorizing toys in some ways could be useful.

Charlie Barbar from Rutgers’ Mason Gross School of Arts explained, “Sometimes it’s useful to have Barbies in one section and maybe some transformers in the other section.”

However, he didn’t believe that toys should explicitly be labeled by gender, nor should children be forced to play with toys only meant for their gender.

Said Barbar: “I don’t think kids are limited to playing with one or the other.”

body.value:
Sterling Ryouta Bryant doesn’t like to be bored. He wears a pair of Beats headphones over his Yankees baseball cap so that whenever he is, J. Cole, Kendrick Lamar, Drake, and Joyner Lucas can come to the rescue.

He feels most at ease when he’s moving and changing and creating. If he thinks his room is looking stale, he changes it. It’s all about "expanding my horizons," he says. Waiting for him at the end of those horizons, he hopes, will be a dream job as a reporter at ESPN or Bleacher Report.

Sterling used to play basketball, but he gave it up early in his high school years at Franklin High School. Now the rising senior writes for the sports section of his school paper, The Warrior.

"I knew that I wanted to keep being involved in the basketball world," he says. "So I figured that sports journalism would be a good way to write about something that I like to do."

He got his first taste of publication in elementary school when as part of a school project he wrote and "published" a superhero book called Stickman. Since then, he’s written a sequel and is currently writing a post apocalyptic story called "Leaving Earth" that he hopes someday sees the ink of a printing press.

After this program, Sterling plans to bring the skills that he has learned to his budding high school newspaper. He admits the paper is "not the best," but as he predicts, change is coming.

attributes.title: NBC Executives Share Advice and Encouragement

body.value:
The National Broadcasting Company, created in 1926, is the first ever network to not only have the first successful early-morning news program but to air the very first commercial on TV as well as become the first to air a broadcast in color and to have the first successful late-night show.

Today, NBC has created the world’s most popular news programs such as Today, Dateline, Meet the Press, and Nighty News.

They are also known around the world for their popular TV shows which attract millions of people all over the world such as Saturday Night Live, Will & Grace, and Seinfeld among many others.

NBC prides itself on its integrity to promote only the most factual news on all their world platforms. They have won many awards across their 92 years of being in the news industry.

Recently the 2018 Boyd Journalism Workshop visited the NBC building in NYC for a one-on-one panel where they got to learn about a variety of journalism professions as well as start to grow their social skills in the journalism industry. The panel included:

  • Val Nicholas -& Vice President and Creative Director, NBC News
  • Sandra Lilley – Managing Editor, NBC Latino
  • Victor Limjoco – Producer for NBC Nightly News with Lester Holt
  • Yvette M. Miley – Senior Vice President and Executive Editor for MSNBC
  • Quiana Burns – Executive Producer at MSNBC
  • Christopher Nelson – Coordinating Producer at MSNBC and NBC News

Yvette M. Miley, senior vice president and executive editor for MSNBC, reminded the group that they are in the age of technology and that as they go through college and find out what path of journalism they love the most to remember that the facts always matter and that it’s beneficial to have more than one talent in this industry.

After introductory comments from the panel, the Boyd Workshop students had a chance to ask questions about NBC and the journalism industry.

"What are some tactics to be the first to report on breaking news?" asked one of the students.

&"You always want to be the first one to report on breaking news but you always want to make sure you gather as many facts as possible while you are reporting on a topic," said Val Nicholas, a vice president and creative director for NBC News. "Gathering reliable sources who you know you can trust is very helpful and making friends with the police can be helpful if reporting on national news. For politics, you want to remain non-biased and report the facts so you can be sent out again."

The journalism workshop expressed their concerns about how to be successful in which ever industry they work in and received many different responses from the panel.

"It’s great to know another language besides from English when you enter a media business because you never know who you may meet or what language they may speak," Said Sandra Lilley, a managing editor for NBC Latino.

Added MSNBC executive producer Quiana Burns, "Making connections and staying in contact with every connection you know will benefit all of you when you’re older and are seeking an internship or guidance during college."

Boyd Workshop students expressed admiration for the amount of variety on the panel and were interested in learning how the NBC executives got to where they are in their careers.

Victor Limjoco, a producer for NBC Nightly News with Lester Holt, told the Boyd Workshop students that as a college student at Northwestern University he found he had to do a lot of catching up to do.

"I didn't know what to expect or how to do half of the things my peers were doing in college," he said. "I had to really make an effort to learn everything about every department of journalism."

body.value:
A giant tile mosaic greeted us as we walked through the heavy revolving doors of Bloomberg offices. As we continued down the hall, it was evident through the massive brown sculpture lining the entry hallway that fostering a creative environment is key to the success of the company.

Some people may not be familiar with the main focus of Bloomberg, but they mostly report on finance, politics, and business. They have a vast reach around the globe with 19,000 staff members in 176 countries, and 2,700 journalists. Also, they are extremely committed to sharing as much news as possible by putting up about 5,000 stories a day in more than 120 countries.

Once we were given our official visitor badges, we took the elevators that were lit up with green and red lights to represent the downs and ups of the stock market. The main floor is complete with snacks, a fish tank, and a koi pond. An interesting fact about Bloomberg is that they showcase their first 22 subscribers to the website by having the same number of koi in the pond.

The terrace has an amazing view of the city and when an employee feels the need to relax during work, they can sit outside on one of the many white benches. The glass windows lining the terrace are decorated with paintings of people -- with no face. This feature is meant to exemplify the fact that the company values diversity in both the stories that they report and their staff.

Bloomberg’s broadcast studies are incredibly impressive and we were able to meet with Paris Wald, senior producer from Bloomberg Television. She gave us some insight about not always having to major in journalism at college.

"You can learn about a subject that matters to you and then you can wind up covering it as a journalist," said Wald. "I think in the Bloomberg newsroom, you’ll find some people studied journalism and just really happen to enjoy business or finance."

Wald took us on a tour of the rest of the offices where we passed desks that were all the same size to promote equality among coworkers. It is important to note that there are no walls in the office, only glass windows, so that "everything is out in the open,"" mentioned Wald. This feature reflects the transparency of journalism.

Once the tour was over, we grabbed snacks from the wide variety of free food available at the office and headed to a presentation on the history and importance of Bloomberg. Jordyn Holman and David Levitt were on a panel talking about their experiences as journalists and their main beat for Bloomberg.

The students felt inspired after our trip to Bloomberg offices, "It is really interesting how Bloomberg focuses on business but it is so pervasive and influential in other aspects of the world," said Josie Wu.

Overall, the trip to Bloomberg gave all the students an insight into the different types of stories that they will be able to cover as journalists in the future

attributes.title: Boyd Teaching Associate Alexis Jennings: A Woman Who Always Finds a Solution

body.value:
The Boyd Workshop's teaching associate, Alexis Jennings, knows a little something about handling difficult situations and overcoming fear.

Consider this. Have you ever had your hand get stuck in an escalator? Well, Jennings did when she was a child. Ok, that doesn't have a thing to do with journalism. But it does speak to Jennings and her knack for calmly finding a solution, something she tries to share with the Boyd Workshop students.

She recently graduated from Monmouth University with a Bachelor's Degree in Communications and a minor in Sports Communications. Alexis is originally from Summit, New Jersey but she moved twice before settling in Monroe Township where she resides today.

Alexis relishes in calming activities like binge watching Netflix with her friends. Her favorite show? Friends.

"I've watched it about four times and I can't get enough of it," said Alexis with a smile. Her favorite character is the 'always relatable' Phoebe due to her quirky personality. At the moment, Alexis is all about The Office.

In addition to her penchant for Netflix, Alexis is an active member of her sorority, Alpha Kappa Alpha.

"I liked what it stood for in terms of sisterhood and community service," Alexis said. "It is powerful."

In terms of the future, Alexis plans on going into sports broadcasting, particularly for football, basketball, and volleyball.
